Field.Label: The plugin offers 2 methods to read messasages 1) python socket calls. This methode does not catch all messages. ie messages with mfg_info etc 2) using commandline tools hcidump and lescan. They work on most RPI flawlessly, but using eg pi-0-w with USB BLE dongle, it likes to get retstarted. The restart takes ~ 1 sec, during that time no messages get received. That should not pose a problem. It should be used as default
.... queries seq. or parallel on THIS rPi:

List.Option: run BLEconnect in sequential in one program

Field.Label: only serial mode is available, paralell seems to overload the RPI sometimes

Field.Label: ... master will restart it if stops running:

The plugin supports several options for hardware reset and UPS etc -A. "shutdown hardwire reset": Connect a GPIO out pin to RUN/REST pin on the board. 1. Then the system can initiate a hardware reset by pulling the GPIO pin down Eg when the RPI hangs and software reset does not work 2. shutDown input pin if pulled down for > 2 secs rpi will do a soft shutdown -B. Support of a PI-HAT UPS board. This setup enables a soft shutdown as well as auto restart when power comes back Tow GPIO pins are used: 1. "shutdown-INPUT" sensing if +5V UPS input to the UPS board is ON. - input to UPS not the +5V to the RPI-, when low: running on battery +5VUPS goes through a resistor divider directly to the GPIO: High if +5 ON, low if off 2. a GPIO output "disable RESET" that goes to a transistor Basis- Emitter to ground, where the Collector disables the +5V raw trigger to restart the PRI, ie pulls it low under normal cuircumstance, hence RESET is only active when RPi is NOT running The software monitors the shutdown-Voltage INPUT pin: if LOW, a counter starts: if > "wait with shutdown" it initiates shutdown (soft then hard) if HIGH it increases the internal counter for battery charge, up to "battery Capacity" Parameter "how long to recharge": is the time it assumes the board needs to fully charge the wait until reboot is shortened if battery is not fully charged +5V UPS trigger: The Board will restart when +5V UPS comes back through a capacitor-resistor-transitor collector connected to the RUN/REST pin. THAT transistor will then be disabled by #2 during normal run. This is enables the RPI to restart after regular shutdown as it does not restart if its +5V is still on, ie battery still working -C. using RPI UPS Pack Version 2 That UPS signals 1. shutdown iminent (set pin ot detect) and 2. Through serial port (TXRX pins 13,14) sends Vin(good/NG), Vout(mV), BatCapleft(%) info. You can select to use shutdown signal pin and or % Battery capacity left to shutdown (if Vin is NG) -D using Alchemy piz ups Version 2 That UPS can be read via i2c: Vin, Vout, Vbat, temperature 1. set i2c 2. set batt capacity , % cap left before rpi shutdown A, B, C, are independent of each other and can be used together

ConfigUI.Field: > ==== Set parameters for iBeacon devices You can tune several parameters like response to signales etc as well as battery, beep, group membership etc ====

Field.Label: == Transition from Up to Down to Expired:

This will overwrite the default setting in config. For normal beacon operation, if no signal is received a beacon after "expirationTime" willl be set to DOWN and after another "expirationTime" it will go to EXPIRED

Field.tooltip: if in a iBeacon does not send a signal within xx seconds it is set to down (set signal to -999)
Field.Label: ... send msg to indigo if xx Seconds no signal

use this to be able to react fast to leaving beacons, used eg in CAR device When no signal is received on the RPI for xx seconds, it sends a "down" message to the plugin. When all RPI that had an "up" signal have send a "down" the beacon will go to down status If set too short an RPI might miss one or 2 messages (timing or signal weak) and will send a down signal, give it enough time to make sure the beacon is really gone

Field.tooltip: rPI will send a message to indigo if the signal strength changes by more than xx dBm, use eg to track someone moving around - going from one room to the next
Field.Label: .... If signal strength (rssi) CHANGE greater than:

List.Option: 4 dBm triggers almost every time, in the noise level
do not use, regular sending of messages

Field.Label: use this to detect beacons that eg leave or enter a room and you want to know quickly

Use this to apply a hystersis factor: - requires a high Signal to switch on = has to be close to RPI - needs a low Signal to switch off = stay on longer eg: on=-60dBm, off=-80dBm walk by the rpi to switch on, stays on as long as in room only after leaving the room signal drops below -80 then normal expiration timer for down/ expired
== Make this device member of group:...
Adding a device to a group will add this device to variable for xx_Count_groupname_ .. Home, Away
== TAG type of beacon, make sure you don't overwrite w the wrong TAG type:

SOME beacons send different message types at different TX power levels. That will create a problem when calculating distance. Setting to only accept the ONE device specific message type from knowBeaconTag file will avoid that.
== How often should we update the signal and distance states in the plugin:

List.Option: as soon as we receive a new message, use this for fast down and CAR models

Field.Label: == Set txPower, use a number to overwrite received value or set to 999 to not overwrite
For proper distance calculations the Signal value at 1 m is required. To calibrate put the beacon 1 m away from the RPI and note the received signal value Put THAT value into this field
== Set Battery parameters enable/ disable, type ..

There are 3 ways battery level can be obtained: 1. gatttool, 2. std ibeacon message, 3. google-Eddystone-TLM message FOR GATT COMMAND type iBeacons (check knownBeaconTags.json file): To be able to use gatttool on rpi requires SSD 7/2018 or GT The properties should be set automatically, this option allows to overwrite the default for this beacon The plugin will READ each beacon every 8 hours: if last successful read >17H, or lastBat. level < 20% It will REPORT (warning log) once a day on beacons, if their last update > 2 days or battery level < 20% The cmds are send to the RPI that is closest to the beacon to be read. You can manually force to read all beacons w action or menu "Get iBeacon battery level.." There are different types of beacons that require differnt methods. Not all beacons support the read of battery level. You can test your iBeacon on the rpi with the following line commands sudo /bin/hciconfig hci0 down;sudo /bin/hciconfig hci0 up sudo /usr/bin/gatttool -b mac# -t public --char-read --uuid=2A19 sudo /usr/bin/gatttool -b mac# -t random --char-read --uuid=2A19 (replace the mac# number with yours). === please note during the time the RPI reads the battery level === === it can not listen to iBeacon signals (< 15s per beacon) ===
There are also beacons that send Battery info as part of std msg in the regular beacon eg Ruuvitag TLM message w battery, temp secs since start and adv count info the msg and TLM messages are automatically recognized and the beacon is setup accordingly

List.Option: YES, use gatttool IF configured in knownBeaconTags file
YES, use std msg, not through GATT commands (eg ruuvitag)
YES, use BLE-TLM message type with LiPo (CRxxx=3.2V)
YES, use BLE-TLM message type with 2 AA(A) (3V)
YES, use BLE-TLM message type with 3 AAA (4.5V)
skip 4am (some beacons beep when battery query runs)

Field.Label: .... check battery level at which hours(4/12/20)-only for gatttool:
some (ie nutale) beacons beep when battery level is checked. This option can disallow the std check at 4 am
Must be pre-configured in knownBeaconTags file:

List.Option: do not show marker, only text

Field.Label: This is for internal communication between plugins. It is a fast and effective way to tell other plugins up/down .. status this requires other plugins to subscribe to this service

if you want to only use certain beacons to trigger on closest beacon to RPI set the others to off. Or if you want to exclude a specific beacon that is stationary and want to see whcih move around beacon is closest

... overwrite the current BLE-MAC number with:

Must not be equal to an existing ACTIVE device. Use this to eg replace an iBeacon with a new one. Write MAC address of new beacon here. This will then ONLY replace the MAC number and keep history of THIS device. ConfigUI.Field: > =======setup BLE sensors you need to supply the MAC number and the RPi which should read the sensor: login to RPI and do sudo hciconfig hci0 down;sleep 1;sudo hciconfig hci0 up;sleep 1;sudo timeout -s INT 50s hcitool lescan find a line like --F1:40:50:49:2A:42 24A2041F -- F1:...:42 is the mac number of your BLE temp sensor; 24A22041F is used on the iphone myBlue-T app to ID the sensor ====

Field.Label: == set color of status column dot to
set State Indicator to GREEN if:
set State Indicator to GREY if:
set State Indicator to RED if:

The conditions will be passed through eval(). Examples: "x > 55" "x < 33" "33 <= x and x <= 66" "x <= 33 or 66 <=x" "1 " to pick color - The sequence is green/grey/red. - If one is satisfied, the others will NOT be evaluated - This will be skipped if all fields are empty or the same - An invalid python "eval()" statement will cause an error - The status column must be a single state - If you leave it blank the defauult device state icon will be used

ConfigUI.Field: > === setup BLE BLERuuviTag. You need to supply the MAC number. Easiest is to run the Ruuvi Station app on your phone and lookup the MAC address The sensors do not need any config, besides power on, They broadcast iBeacon format packages (1/sec) with additional data They send T, H, P, Acceleration in mG (accelleration-X,Y,Z,Total=sqrt(x*x+y*y+z*z)) The calculated value MAGturn is (delta x,delta y, delta z vs last values) in %. it indicates a turn of the sensor, while accelerationTotal might stay constant. In addition measurement count and movement count is supplied. The battery level is calculated as (BatteryVolt-2900)/(3200-2900) in % As the sensor sends iBeacon Signals ~1/second it can be used as a regular iBeacon device check only RPIs that are installed, checked RPi that do not exist will be ignored ===

ConfigUI.Field: > === setup BLE blueradio sensor bug. You need to supply the MAC number. You can get the mac number w "detect new beacons.." menu", press sw1 on sensor until blue led blinks, check for BLEsensorbug tag in plugin.log The sensors need to be setup with the app blue sense, it has extensive help Enable temp, light and movement = door, set frequency to 1-2 secs, You can set various resolutions etc for light, best to use is range=64,000; res=16bit The sensor does not broadcast xyz values only on/off= vertical/horizontal position Switch of alerts Check only RPIs that are installed, checked RPi that do not exist will be ignored ===

ConfigUI.Field: > === Xiaomi MiJia Bluetooth temp(-9C...60C) and humidity sensor (LYWSD03MMC). The square one not round - check eg: https ref below This sensor requires to have a second BLE dongle in the RPI, as it needs to connect to the sensor for ~ 12+ seconds to receive the values. Or while offline it will block the BLE channel for ~ 15+ seconds That will block any other function for that BLE dongle on the RPI You can find the MAC number using the plugin tool detect new beacons, look for LYWSD03MMC or XiaomiMiBLETempHumSquare ===

ConfigUI.Field: > === Ink Bird Pool 01B Temperature sensor. This sensor requires to have a second BLE dongle in the RPI, as it needs to connect to the sensor for ~ 3+ seconds to receive the values. Setup i2cBME680 temp pressure humidity sensor on individual rPis.. connect 3.3, GND, SDA,SCL. It measures Temp, humidity and pressure like eg bme280 and in addition a gas value that is a resistance that changes with air quality. In clean air the resistance is the highest, if it senses eg VOC gases the resistance becomes lower. airQuality/GasSore is (current resistance) / baseline The program can use differnt modes for airQuality/gasScore calibration: - auto calibration: it will run until it finds stable gas resistance and sets that as its basline to be clean air, if the values goes above that baseline it will recalibrate and use the new baseline once calibrated, it will save value to bme680.Calibration file on RPi - or you can overwrite that by setting your own value statically. - or read last calibration from calibration file, if error do regular calibration steps The sensor read rate will impact the baseline, that is due to the heat cycle if you change the read cyle time, it must be recalibrated After some days of running in clean air, proposed setup is: ====set baseline to fixed value of clean air====

Field.tooltip: select pi- server number and then click on confirm
Field.Label: select rPi-server to which the sensor is connect to:
use TCA9548A multiplexer for this sensor:
Set Baseline or calibrate automatically if AirQuality gt:

List.Option: dynamic, first read calibration from file (stored from last run)
dynamic, start from scratch each time it starts
read calibration from file (stored from last run)
dynamic, change if > 101 percent, likely to sensitive

Field.Label: Setting to other than dynamic, will require user to manage gas baseline
Changing how often the sensor is read will require a new calbration, it might take an hour to be stable

delta value (%) to trigger indigo update:
send update to indigo every xx secs(overwrites RPI set):
Text mapping of airquality% to limits:
format: limitTop=text/.../0=text, will map airquality from 0-100% to text items, you must at least 3. Default: 95=Good/85=Average/75=Little Bad/65=Bad/50=Worse/0=Very Bad

Setup i2c amg88xx infrared camera sensor on individual rPis.. connect 3.3, GND, SDA,SCL. It measures - all temp values are converted to std temp (set in config) -Ambient Temperature, -Average Temperature of pixels, -MinimumPixel = min Temperature val of all pixels, -MaximumPixel = max Temperature val of all pixels, -Movement: delta pixel Temp to last measuremnt, large val indicates Movement: 100*sqrt(sum ((pixT-lastT)/(pixT+lastT))**2)/64 -Uniformity of pixel temperature, low value indicates Structure: 100/sqrt(sum ((pixT-aveT)/(pixT+aveT))**2)/64 you can setup - number of measurement per second - delta value to trigger sending update to indigo

Setup Lidar360 sensor on individual rPis.. connect sensor to USB port and power definitions: enpty room: set calibration (menu or action) when nobody is in room trigger: when N dots next to each other have > Z a distance change events are triggered current - last values and current - calibrated room vcalues are 2 different triggers when the value is + the distance is bigger, hence = leaving or recalibration is needed when the value is - things are closer to the sensor = approacing or presence current - last triggers on faster movement, current - calibrated room triggers show the differnce of now to when room was calibrated. to improve the quality of data 6+ sequential 360 measurements are taken and compared to current or calibrated room, if the largest of the measurements has sum of Z > threshold: event is triggered

===For all following numbers you can use simple number but also eg 1./255 or more complicated formulas - make sure you use float numbers, not integers The sequence of application is: 0. value: (raw+offset)*multiplier 1. resistor: R = feedResistor/(feedVolt/INPUT-1.) w sensor to Ground 2. min/max range: SensValue = (INPUT-MinRange)(MaxRange-MinRange) 3. 1./value if selected 4. log: value = Log10(value) // linear: value = value 5. value = (value+offset2)*multiplier2 6. format 7. unit added to end of string

MINIMAL setup: Sensor output to a GPIO and ground-- polarity does not matter, connect 12V - polarity does not matter, set mode to medium sensitivity.
For NORMAL -dynamic- setup connect sensor output, and 4 GPIOs to 4 relays to 12V, dipsw 1,2,5/ground to sensor, set the GPIOs used below Every time the mode changes the 12 V power is recycled to activate the setting Dip-sw 1,2 set sensitivity, Dip-sw 5 sets mode "any rain" or "count buckets" General info: In check for rain mode the signal stays on for an extened period of time ie 30 secs .. several minutes The progam on the RPi will reset the sensor after 30 sec to enable a new rain test During heavy rain and in "High sensitivity" mode the relay clicks ~ twice per sec until count finished ie number of buckets reported
use relay 1. GPIO connected relays or 2. .. wiki.52pi.com/index.php/DockerPi_04_Channel_Relay_SKU:_EP-0099 relay 1 is towards +3v +5V rpi pins
Default pins for dynamic mode: pin 2 +5V to relay board, to run the board pin 8 GPIO14/52relay4 : 12 V relay #4 pin 10 GPIO15/52relay3 : dip sw 5 relay #3 pin 12 GPIO18/52relay2 : dip sw 2 relay #2 pin 14 ground to relay board pin 16 GPIO23/52relay1 : dip sw 1 relay #1 pin 18 GPIO24 : input = sensor output relay on sensor board; pin 20 ground : input = ... polarity does not matter power supply: +12V -- relay # 4 NC ---- sensor power in; polarity does not matter -12V -------------------- sensor power in; power is delivered when relay is off relay NO # 3 sw 5 sensor relay NO # 2 sw 2 sensor relay NO # 1 sw 1 sensor connect middle of relay(1,2,3) out 1,2,3 to ground on sensor NO = normally open NC = normally closed Static mode ie fixed sensitivity does not require any relays to be setup. any rain mode: switches to drizzel after 10 seconds, to rain after 140 seconds and stays at rain until ~ 140 seconds after last drop High med low sensitive simply count buckets, switch to no rain after xx secs set in parameter ( NO = normally open contact, NC = normally closed contact for relays)

This sensor will count if 2 or more INPUTpulse sensors trigger within a coincidence time interval the INPUTpulse devices must be on the same RPI min time interval is 1mSec, max is 3 minutes. if you select 2 channels then both channels must fire in the specified time interval if 4 channels are selected all 4 must fire in the same time interval == Explanation of dev states: - count = total count of pulses since last reset - countPrevious = total count of pulses since lasty reset previous value - countPerSecond = delta counts between 2 measurements, at low feq eg this goes 0 1 0 0 0 0 1 - countTime = timestamp(year-month ... :sec) of last count change - countPerSecSmooth = delta Count / time between previous change of count and now eg this goes 0.5 0.4 0.3 0.2 0.2 0.3 0.4 0.5 in comparison to countPerSecond - countTimePrevious = delta time in secs bwteen now and previous change of counts - countPerMinute = Count delta in last 60 seconds - countPerMinuteScaled = Count delta in last 60 seconds * scale factor set in dev edit - countPerHour = Count delta in last 1 hour - countPerDays = Count delta in last 24 hours - countPerSecondMaxLastHour max of countPerSecond in last hour - countperMinute min/max/today/yesterday = min/max of countPerMinute today and yesterday

==Enter local action executed directly on RPI: --- for BURST, LONG, CONTINUOS events, you can use -Any unix command eg "ping 192.168.1.1" -Or /usr/bin/curl --user userid:password -X PUT -d value="abc" http://ip#:servport/variables/xxx -Or "sudo reboot" or "sudo shutdown -h now"- -Or GPIO 18 on/off: "gpio -g mode 18 out;gpio -g write 18 1;gpio -g write 18 0" -Or GPIO 18 toggle: "gpio -g mode 18 out;if (gpio -g read 18 | grep 1 ); then gpio -g write 18 0; else gpio -g write 18 1 ;

This sensor setup is good to detect pulses into a GPIO: Pulses = Signals are detected with GPIO events, depening on RPI max frequence varies, RPI3++ can do 100hz use bounceTime and or deadTime to tune for bad signals It will set state count (number of pulses) and lastCountSecs (timestamp) and frequency New pulse is detected under the following conditions: if time between signals > deadTime and bounce time Indigo gets updated if time -lastUpdate > "min secs between indigo updates" In addition you can setup == BURST detection : min y signals in a time window of xx secs, eg min 5 signals in 2 seconds It will set state lastBurstSecs (timestamp) of the last BURST detected == CONTINUOSevent detection = requires a pulse every xx seconds(timewindow) to stay Up: eg with pulses every 1 second, timewindow =2 seconds , state will stay Up until pulses stop It will set state lastContinuousEventSecs (-Stop) timestamp of the last continuousEvent start/stop Count and BURST and continuousEvents are independent of each other You can only use ONE definition of edge per gpio pin (not RISING in one device and FALLING in another for the same pin) == Explanation of dev states: - count = total count of pulses since last reset - countPrevious = total count of pulses since lasty reset previous value - countPerSecond = delta counts between 2 measurements, at low feq eg this goes 0 1 0 0 0 0 1 - countTime = timestamp(year-month ... :sec) of last count change - countPerSecSmooth = delta Count / time between previous change of count and now eg this goes 0.5 0.4 0.3 0.2 0.2 0.3 0.4 0.5 in comparison to countPerSecond - countTimePrevious = delta time in secs bwteen now and previous change of counts - countPerMinute = Count delta in last 60 seconds - countPerMinuteScaled = Count delta in last 60 seconds * scale factor set in dev edit - countPerHour = Count delta in last 1 hour - countPerDays = Count delta in last 24 hours - countPerSecondMaxLastHour max of countPerSecond in last hour - countperMinute min/max/today/yesterday = min/max of countPerMinute today and yesterday

Field.Label: Setup switchbot bot "relay" on individual rPis through BLE-connect These mechanical switches get their commands through bluetooth messages. Indigo sends the messages to one RPI via tcpip, that rpi sends the commands via BLE This works reliable when 2 BLE dongles are on an rpi, eg the internal +1 external you can also set the switchbot remotely through an ssh command (eg iPhone shortcut through vpn): ssh pi@ip# of the selected RPi; then echo '{"mac":"xx:xx:xx:xx:xx","onOff":"1"}' > ~/pibeacon/temp/switchbot.cmd This device will get its battery level from its brother device, the beacon device with the same mac number, IF it is set to beacon type = switchbot To force an update of the mode and switch time use menu/piBeacon/Set params on switchbot bot

Field.tooltip: select pi- server number and then click on confirm
Field.Label: select rPi-server to which the relay is connect to:
length of time to hold switch:

Setup switchbot bot "curtain" on individual rPis through BLE-connect These mechanical switches get their commands through bluetooth messages. Indigo sends the messages to one RPI via tcpip, that rpi sends the commands via BLE This works reliable when 2 BLE dongles are on an rpi, eg the internal +1 external you can also set the switchbot remotely through an ssh command (eg iPhone shortcut through vpn): ssh pi@ip# of the selected RPi; then echo '{"mac":"xx:xx:xx:xx:xx","pos":"100"}' > ~/pibeacon/temp/switchbot.cmd for close or "pos":"x" for move to position x or "pos":"p" for pause This device will get its battery level from its brother device, the beacon device with the same mac number, IF it is set to beacon type = switchbotCurtain

Setup circular clock on neopixel devices. It supports different models, they all need have one or multiple rings with neopixel LEDs The hour/minute/seconds are shown with one or more LEDs on one or multiple rings First define how many rings and number of LED per ring you have Then define which ring(s) should show HH, MM, SS and what color and if it should show 1 or 3 adjacent LED (only if you use 1 ring for that quantity) If you select eg 3 rings for HH (eg rings w 12,24,48 LED) the dots would create a line like the small hand of a clock Then select if you want to put makers on the clock eg at 10/20/30/40/50 minutes in dimm light (set RGB value) You can dimm the light through an action and send it to the device - eg at night
default: pin# 2(+5V), 12(GPIO18 = signal), 6(Gnd). You need to use a level shifter for the signal

Setup stepper motor parameters: You can chose between 5 pole unipolar and 2 coils bipolar stepper motors. These motors must be driven by chips: ULN2003 is a simple set of darlington transitors, current up to 250mA It is used for the 5 pole unipolar motor L9110 or L298N can be used to drive bipolar 2 coil motors in full and half step modes A4988 (8V-35V) and DRV8834(2.5V-8V) are more sophisticated. They are almost 100% pin compatible Can drive bipolar 2 coil motors in 1,1/2,1/4,1/8,1/16 (and 1/32) step size you need to configure the pins on the chips to set the step size Can configure enable / sleep / reset and fault pins They are currently only used to switch the motor ON at start, but you could also simply hardwire the pins at the chip directly You are able to use multiple motors on the same RPI (tested w 2) limited by the number of GPIOs available and CPU power depending on driver type Use an indigo ACTION "Send commands to stepper motor .." to drive the motor #of steps, direction, delays ... can be send in single or multiple sets You can use up to 3 GPIO input pins to control the range of the motor If one of thes GPIO goes High/low the motor will stop. This can be enabled / configured in each action separately. Here you define the GPIO pin numbers and refer to them in the actions as GPIO#0 / 1 / 2

2 bipolar coils bridge - DRV8834 set steps sice on chip jumpers
2 bipolar coils bridge - A4988 set steps sice on chip jumpers

Field.Label: Setup devices that make up the Car home/away status: First Beacon is a battery (eg AAA) power beacon, fixed in car Second Beacon is USB powered to indicate if engine is running Third .. fifths are the beacons connected to the car key rings States: ==status: HOME if (battery or USB or (all of the Keys) ==status: AWAY if not(battery or USB or (all of the keys) ==engine: ON: USB=ON; OFF:USB=Off; "": if AWAY ==motion: STOP: HOME and USB=off; LEAVING: USB=ON and HOME > 40 seconds; ARRIVING switching to home
